Award.AwardTitle: SimHUB: Enabling Multidisciplinary Collaboration with Containerization Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports travel to enable collaborations among National Science Foundation (NSF)- and Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST)-supported researchers. The PI, Dr. Jian Tao, will travel to Japan to collaborate with Dr. Saneyasu Yamaguchi's research group from Kogakuin University to improve the Input/Output (I/O) performance of container-based virtualization. Dr. Jian Tao will also work with members from the South Big Data Regional Innovation Hub to promote and support collaborations among US and international researchers on coastal hazards research.

Cloud computing technologies, especially containers built upon the containerization technologies, enable an extremely flexible and portable computing environment that could be tailored to meet a wide spectrum of computing requirements for scientific research. In order to prepare traditional computational science communities for the existing and upcoming cloud-like computing and networking systems, this collaboration will enable the design and development of Simulation Hub (SimHUB), a web-based computing platform for scientific applications on containers. It enables rapid sharing and integration of modeling applications and computational tools among connected communities. It also provides a collaborative platform for multidisciplinary and integrative research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SimHUB is a web-based computing platform for scientific applications on containers. It enables rapid sharing and integration of modeling  applications and computational tools among connected communities. It also provides a collaborative platform to enable multidisciplinary and integrative research on cloud-like computing and networking systems.

In this US-Japan (NSF-JST) collaborative project, the PI worked with Japanese collaborators to focus on: (1)  the design and development of the web-based SimHUB platform (led by the PI) and (2) the performance improvement of Docker-based parallel simulations that are enabled by SimHUB (led by Dr. Saneyasu Yamaguchi from Kogakuin University in Japan). 

The design and development of SimHUB is based on the SIMULOCEAN platform that is part of the Coastal Resilience Collaboratory project supported by NSF via the CyberSEES program (Award 1539567). Our team modified the SIMULOCEAN platform to make it agnostic to the applications/models. The application specific analysis tools are now integrated into the Jupyter notebook that is distributed with the application image on the public Docker repository. Such changes transformed SimHUB into a generic platform that could be deployed to launch, monitor, and manage any containerized scientific and engineering applications. The PI presented and discussed the work at the XSEDE ECSS Symposium on March 20, 2018 [4].

Additionally, our team investigated the performance issues in using Docker containers in a highly consolidated virtual environment. The primary objective is to achieve high consolidation without large performance decline. We compared the performance with and without container-based virtualization, then demonstrated that container-based virtualization can provide similar performance to that without virtualization in CPU processing and networking but cannot provide comparable performance in I/O processing with the default setup in I/O intensive applications. By exploring the relationship between the number of containers and the obtained performance, we showed that the I/O performance severely decreases as the number of consolidated servers increase. The work was presented at 2017 IEEE International Conference on Big Data at Boston in Dec 2017 [1].

In addressing the I/O performance issues in Docker, we evaluated the performance of file operations on  OverlayFS, which is used in Docker to improve I/O performance. In particular, we focused on the performance of file writing involving copy_up and showed that the performance is severely low. We found that the synchronization is causing the performance degradation and presented a method to improve the I/O performance by disabling the unnecessary synchronization. We showed that, with synchronization turned off, the writing performance is up to 680 times faster. The work was presented at BITS 2018: 2nd IEEE International Workshop on Big Data and IoT Security in Smart Computing and 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) 2018 [2, 3].

References:

  1. J Kon, N Mizusawa, A Umezawa, S Yamaguchi, J Tao, Highly consolidated servers with container-based virtualization, Big Data (Big Data), 2017 IEEE International Conference on, 2472-2479

  2. N Mizusawa, J Kon, Y Seki, J Tao, S Yamaguchi, Performance Improvement of File Operations on OverlayFS for Containers, 2018 IEEE International Conference on Smart Computing (SMARTCOMP), 297-302

  3. Improving I/O Performance in Container with OverlayFS, N Mizusawa, J Kon, Y Seki, J Tao, S Yamaguchi, 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data), 5395-5395
